channel.title: Comments on: Wired vs Ad Blockers

item.title: By: Aaron Toponce
item.dc:creator: Aaron Toponce
item.description: If advertisers didn't completely obliterate trust, and web designers didn't completely destroy screen real estate with ad presence, that seems like a likely possibility. Unfortunately, nothing positive comes out of online advertisements for the end user, and everything negative- slower page loads, larger HTTP Tx, malware distribution, cramped site design, and increased system load.
item.content:encoded: If advertisers didn’t completely obliterate trust, and web designers didn’t completely destroy screen real estate with ad presence, that seems like a likely possibility. Unfortunately, nothing positive comes out of online advertisements for the end user, and everything negative- slower page loads, larger HTTP Tx, malware distribution, cramped site design, and increased system load.

item.title: By: Joseph Scott
item.dc:creator: Joseph Scott
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2016/02/16/wired-vs-ad-blockers/#comment-4457">Jake Spurlock</a>.
I suspect few people using ad-blockers will do that. You'd need to be very convincing that none of your ad networks are abusing their powers ( or, you know, distributing malware ). Trust has been eroded so badly that getting it back is going to be very hard.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Jake Spurlock.

I suspect few people using ad-blockers will do that. You’d need to be very convincing that none of your ad networks are abusing their powers ( or, you know, distributing malware ). Trust has been eroded so badly that getting it back is going to be very hard.

item.title: By: Jake Spurlock
item.dc:creator: Jake Spurlock
item.description: Doesn't take hacking, just whitelist WIRED and you get the content for free. An easy trade in our book. We just went live with this!
item.content:encoded: Doesn’t take hacking, just whitelist WIRED and you get the content for free. An easy trade in our book. We just went live with this!

item.title: By: Joseph Scott
item.dc:creator: Joseph Scott
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2016/02/16/wired-vs-ad-blockers/#comment-4455">Chris Rudzki</a>.
That is definitely an angle this that they have to consider. I would certainly be less likely to link to an article that was behind a paywall.
If they implement an easy way to bypass the paywall, then the ad-blockers will leverage that in a heart beat.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Chris Rudzki.

That is definitely an angle this that they have to consider. I would certainly be less likely to link to an article that was behind a paywall.

If they implement an easy way to bypass the paywall, then the ad-blockers will leverage that in a heart beat.

item.title: By: Chris Rudzki
item.dc:creator: Chris Rudzki
item.description:
I'm curious about the impact this will have on traffic and other kinds of growth. I'd have to imagine folks will be less inclined to link to an article on such a site, so an article's potential to go viral would probably suffer.
I wonder how they'd address this. I know, for example, if you check out a NY Times article from Google News, that the paywall is bypassed.
item.content:encoded:
I’m curious about the impact this will have on traffic and other kinds of growth. I’d have to imagine folks will be less inclined to link to an article on such a site, so an article’s potential to go viral would probably suffer.

I wonder how they’d address this. I know, for example, if you check out a NY Times article from Google News, that the paywall is bypassed.

item.title: By: Joseph Scott
item.dc:creator: Joseph Scott
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2016/02/16/wired-vs-ad-blockers/#comment-4453">Aaron Toponce</a>.
My gut feeling is this is an arms race that Wired will not be able to win. Their best hope is to avoid letting it get to that point in the first place.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Aaron Toponce.

My gut feeling is this is an arms race that Wired will not be able to win. Their best hope is to avoid letting it get to that point in the first place.

item.title: By: Aaron Toponce
item.dc:creator: Aaron Toponce
item.description: Fantastic writeup. It seems that Wired recognized that putting all articles behind a paywall will most certainly negatively impact their business model, so they seems to have settled on a middle-ground: ads or paywall. Well, as you mentioned, let's see what wins out- stealth ad blocking or paying for subscriptions. Somehow, as you concluded, I'm willing to bet the former wins over the latter.
item.content:encoded: Fantastic writeup. It seems that Wired recognized that putting all articles behind a paywall will most certainly negatively impact their business model, so they seems to have settled on a middle-ground: ads or paywall. Well, as you mentioned, let’s see what wins out- stealth ad blocking or paying for subscriptions. Somehow, as you concluded, I’m willing to bet the former wins over the latter.
